pros: - Supportive team structure and consistent positive attitude. - Ability to engage with a wide spectrum of creatives, students, alumni, & community partners.
cons: - General University issue of faculty/staff restructuring.

pros: - Coworkers were always fantastic - Cheapest housing option on campus - Nice job perks (like moving in early)
cons: - Management was extremely hit-or-miss - Not always understanding of you being a student first - Dealing with extremely sensitive/stressful situations on the regular

review_title: Exhausting Work Culture and Performative People
pros: -Great benefits package -Convenient Parking
cons: - Constant Scope Creep -No potential for advancement (unless you wait for a position's retirement) -Terrible upper management -Disorganization and expectation of underpaid staff to "fix it" -Preference for staying in the past instead of keeping up with the present in terms of technology and culture. -Low salary -Passive Aggressive Leadership and Decision Making -Lack of care of diversity in the middle of a predominantly diverse city. -Blatant favoritism and no faith in HR to make a difference.

job_title: Full Time Faculty in Baltimore, MD

review_title: Chill, perfect if you like working independently in the recording studio
job_title: Recording Studio Technician in Baltimore, MD
pros: Did a lot of independent learning: - Recording bands, podcasts, musicians, vocalists, and voice-over. - Assisting and mentoring students with their Sound Program projects. - Handling setup and teardown of audio equipment. - Patching and maintaining instruments, microphones, and monitors. Jason Sloan's a great boss, extremely hands-off and chill but helpful whenever needed.
cons: The administration of MICA continuously had issues processing my salary, which was very stressful and was an overall headache to fix. A common pattern you'll find at this university is excellence among faculty and students then difficulty/bureaucracy with its administration.

pros: i made great connections to coworkers and staff in my division

pros: Two or more days of remote work is available in most units

review_title: Great school, good people good culture, a bit unorganized, pay is good since unionization
pros: Above average adjunct pay. Support team and deans and the college in general very friendly easy to work with.
cons: Support for online adjuncts can be hit or miss, depending on who is doing the supporting. There seems to be a lot of turnover in that respect. Be aware that if you're going to go on campus in person with any regularity you'll have to have not only the covid shots, but a flu shot as well. A flu shot? Really?? Finance department was lacking in prior years but no problems most recently- but hey, what do you expect? It's an art school.

pros: Great community and students are passionate
cons: No benefits for part time faculty

job_title: Data Entry Clerk in Baltimore, MD

pros:
- The people you have the opportunity to work with are amazing. 
- Benefits are great. At the time I worked here there was a 9% employee match on your retirement contributions.
cons: - Leadership has made a lot of mistakes throughout the pandemic. There are a lot of growing pains happening. This includes layoffs, and shrinking departments with no room for staff staying to operate at their current capacity levels. Burnout, low morale, and a high frequency of staff turnover are definitely an issue.

review_title: MICA Finance team is healthy, supportive coworkers
pros: Coworkers- they will help me out whenever I need it, they're non-judgmental, and my upper management team are great leaders. There's no toxic work environment at all in the department I work at which makes a really big difference.
cons: Massive economic downfalls have happened due to post-COVID and the monkeypox outbreak (out of our control). This is unfortunate for those affected.

pros: Finally have a new exhibitions director- thank god!
cons: Old director could come back?

pros: A lot of staff members understand and relate to the struggles. If you’re an artist you have access to tools and even staff gallery exhibits.
cons: Terrible upper management. Played the “Gottca game” but always pretended to have an open door and open mind. Job was difficult to perform because tools were not made available lower level techs. Security was very very rude to everyone. They claim to be a diverse school being in Baltimore but they basically just recruit kids from China there. HR isn’t even real and now they call their selves PB&C, what a joke…

review_title: a good job for someone desperate
pros: Some staff and employees are wonderful. Good benefits package and retirement. Access to Adobe Creative Cloud and equipment. Experience depends on department. Entry level positions are only a good job for if you are right out of college, a student, or like working around students. Progressive and LGBTQ+ community friendly. If you want a job, not a career, you work here.
cons:
-Dirt pay for being more than overqualified, at their lowest pay and full time, your take home pay per month will be less than $2000
-Some guards are downright mean to not just staff, but students too. Will cut you off mid sentence multiple times while you calmly explain things to them, pray you don’t have to interact with the vile ones
-You don’t actually get credit for their college courses after 90 days, only for open studies courses
-Removed most safety protocol in order to open campus for the fall semester, ensures that students and faculty will inevitably get infected
-Buildings have an absolute no eating inside policy for covid. Which I get, but there is no designated spaces at all for eating as a full time employee. You get to see all of your fellow coworkers sit outside in 95 degree heat and sun
-Corruption in some departments and at the top is appalling and disgusting
-Benefits are the only reason people stay
-Read what other employees have written

pros: Great environment and sense of community within my subdivision, most of the time things were very casual and I genuinely enjoyed going into work to contribute.
cons: The schools administration itself is a trash can fire. Aside from that, the work we do is very physical and it's easy to get injured if you don't know what you're doing. So considering that labor alongside how every other office on campus depends on ours, it would be nice to see better benefits and pay.

review_title: Appearance of inclusion belies the reality of the top heavy boy’s club that values profit over all else
pros:
Union helps negotiate better pay and treatment and works to expand opportunities and access for part time and adjunct employees.
Staff,  students and faculty are excellent and  make you want to come to work. Staff works hard, but is underfunded and poorly supported.

Full time faculty is treated well.
cons:
The appearance of diversity and inclusion belies the reality of a top heavy boys club that looks after its own and values profit above all. 
Sex,  age and racial discrimination is rampant. It’s a boys club at the top where decisions get made; adjuncts are bullied by administration, diversity is a veneer, part time and adjunct pay is low,  benefits are non existent as overcompensated administration tells outright lies to faculty, especially adjuncts, regarding salary and benefits and works to keep them low. Partners, husbands and wives of faculty and administration are given hiring preference and contracts. Sexual, age and racial discrimination and harrassment is not addressed. Younger, less experienced adjuncts (new grads) are hired to edge out older,  more experienced professors who make more money.

pros: great instructor to work with
cons: none that I can think of

pros: Mentorship, air conditioning, lots of restrooms
cons: Pay to park, Workday App can be tricky to navigate but help is always available

pros: Amazing students attend the school.
cons: Poor leadership in charge of the school.

pros: Love working here! Excellent environment
cons: Nothing bad to say about it

review_title: Worst Experience of my Mental Health Life
job_title: Residential Life Coordinator in Baltimore, MD
pros: People from other departments are cool.
cons:
This place is a disaster. They start Reslife RLC's at $29,000. The range is $29,000 to $33,000 and that is WITH A MASTER'S DEGREE. They try to include the housing as compensation but it is NOT worth the hassle. You have to do laundry with the students, the meal plans are not reloaded (110 swipes) if you run out, and they expect you to use your own car for programs/staff outings. 

The department has no structure and the Vice President said he has never had anyone ask for an employee handbook while working there. There is no handbook or institutional knowledge aside from the fact that the Director gets access to your emails and Google Drive when you leave so anything you created, he presents as his own. 

They threaten insubordination when you refuse to be overworked without compensation and when you choose to protect your own mental health.

The Director constantly throws his staff under the bus to other Directors.

There is a lack of leadership, cohesiveness  and overall trust within the department. It is really in shambles and for $18-19 an hour, it is NOT worth it at all. This is why they have such a high turnover rate.

pros: The students and family are a pleasure to work with. Some of the staff are extremely nice and usually management is flexible regarding time off if you need it. Pay is nice.
cons: Management can be very disrespectful and condescending. Snootiness towards others based on their job title is open, blatant, and extremely common. I have seen with my own eyes the same director asking one person if it was okay to tell her what to do, apologize for having to give her orders, etc. and literally snip at another, bark out orders, respond with duh to questions, etc. and even downright walk away while the person was still talking and asking for help telling her to get it together. The difference? Their job titles were different. One was a lowly receptionist, the other an EA. It was sad and disgusting and no one checked the Director. Lower level staff (security, janitorial, student workers) are given meanial tasks - such as washing dishes, and usually aren't even spoken to at all.

pros: Most of the students are lovely people.
cons: Can't list my detailed title on here in fear. Be wary of what you're getting into if you're looking to apply. Toxic power dynamics, no support structure for staff, and a recklessly laid back attitude set staff up to fail. The amount of work you'll do and stress you'll go through will never be compensated even close to what it should (unless you're one of the 10,000 deans at the school). Very top heavy. People at the bottom do all the work and are underpaid. There's a lot of potential here with complete reform.

review_title: Not a great place to work
pros: The environment! Absolutely incredible group of people. You are constantly surrounded by art of so many varieties, and many creative young people who have incredible drive.
cons: The place is poorly managed. I worked in the photo department. I actually found out that the women in my department (Staff) were getting paid less than the men. Thankfully, after months of negotiating with HR, we got that settled.. But, in general, MICA underpays their employees. They prefer to spend their money on fancy new buildings that don't function well.

review_title: Great Culture, Supportive Development of Self
job_title: Corporate Parts Manager in Baltimore, MD
pros:
+ Connected and caring community

+ PRO and a CON - Highly Relational Institution. Knowing people and keeping a good relationship with people is an important asset.
cons:
+ At the time (and maybe now?) they did not compare/contrast institutions salaries with those in Washington DC - which kept salaries fairly low.

+ PRO and a CON - Highly Relational Institution. Knowing people and keeping a good relationship with people is an important asset.

+ In the realm of student affairs - volunteering for other offices is a must - helpful for expanding your experience, but a drain on work/life balance

pros: It's a simple minimum-wage job and they are obligated to schedule around your classes, which can be a problem if you apply for an outside job. You don't need any prior experience since it's based on need (so this can also be a nice way to get experience for your resume) Usually the jobs are very easy, often just basic office work. I worked in 3 different departments until I voluntarily dropped the workstudy program, and my average duties were:  cleaning, filing, basic research, shredding, running errands, working the front desk (or the equivalent of), answering the phone, etc. If there wasn't any work to be done, most of my supervisors were happy to let me do homework in the office.
cons:
You might think that doing workstudy at an art school would involve more art - the majority of the positions are just office work. So they can serve as resume padding, but you probably won't gain any experience or knowledge relevant to the field you're studying. 

Some of the departments that have workstudy positions open honestly do not need workstudies, and if you have a lot of homework that can't be done on a laptop, you may feel like you are wasting your time for 5 hours a week. 

As a need-based student, you have little to no control over what position you are assigned. Sometimes the positions you are assigned may require you to interact with a lot of strangers aka "customer service skills" and some people are not skilled in that area or are very uncomfortable with it. Since you are getting paid and presumably have a need for the money, you kind of have to suck it up, but if you have serious or debilitating social anxiety, it's something to consider.

pros: Being around other creatives is amazing! I felt I had an amazing amount of autonomy and felt I could be myself
cons: This school is run by old racists and misogynists- beware. So many of their outdated practices are grandfathered in and it reflects in their internal structure. It is the oldest accredited art college in the nation, and their processes reflect this.

pros: Small college so it’s easy to get to know your colleagues. Campus environment is friendly and supportive. Great benefit package.
cons: Salary scale very low compared to other institutions. Turnover can be high due to low salary. It’s so not easy to move up in rank. Unless someone above you leaves, you’re pretty much stuck in that same position, unless a new position is created in your department.
